Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Optimizing non-pharmaceutical and pharmaceutical interventions for controlling COVID-19 at the community-level
Award.AbstractNarration:
During emerging infectious disease outbreaks, such as the current novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, mathematical models are important tools to help inform public health recommendations and best utilization of limited resources. This research will develop and analyze data-driven mathematical models to predict the spread and evaluate the success of various public health intervention strategies to control COVID-19 in the US and abroad. The models will account for the characteristics of the pathogen, the variation of transmission that occur within community and in hospital settings, and geographical difference in transmission. The broader impacts from these models will provide real-time information to assist public health officials and decision-makers in making critical decisions on COVID-19 control policies and resource allocation.

Standard modeling approach such as compartmental population-based approach may not be suitable for modeling the spread of COVID-19, due to the high-level of heterogeneity of such systems, disease pathways, population makeup, host interactions on different levels of organization (household, workplace/school, social activities), and adaptive features of human behavior. The investigators will employ an individual-based modeling approach (IBM) that will accommodate such local heterogeneities. The investigators will use social, demographic, and epidemiological data of COVID-19 cases in the US and Korea, as well as hospital-level and city-level contact tracing data of COVID-19 in Wuhan, China, to parameterize their models. First, they will develop an IBM hospital-based model to explore different hospital-based interventions for mitigating the risk of nosocomial transmission of COVID-19 between patients and healthcare workers. Second, they will develop an IBM community-based model to evaluate and identify optimal non-pharmaceutical and potential pharmaceutical interventions for COVID-19 control in different local communities (city-county scale). The non-pharmaceutical interventions will include, amongst others: case isolation at home or hospitals, voluntary self-quarantine, stopping mass gathering, closure of schools, universities, or workplaces, and social distancing such as reduction of contacts, wearing of protective masks, and reduction of individuals' movements. Pharmaceutical interventions will include novel vaccines and antiviral therapies.

This RAPID award is made by the Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases Program in the Division of Environmental Biology, using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Emerging infectious disease outbreaks, such as the current novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, call for new approaches, mathematical models and computer tools to help inform  public health bodies, and guide control policies, resource allocation and best utilization of preventive strategies. Such disease and the means of their control can be explored on different levels and scales, ranging from large (country / regional) scales, down to local communities (cities, counties) or individual enterprises (workplaces, schools, hospitals et al). The focus of our proposal is disease spread and control at the local level. Standard population-based modeling approaches are not suitable at such scales, due to multiple heterogeneities: disease pathways, population makeup and social interactions on different levels of organization.

Our research project has developed a novel individual based modeling approach (IBM) for Covid-19 that accommodates disease specifics, and takes into account social interactions at local community level (household, workplace/school et al). Conventional approaches to IBM community interactions typically assume either (i) random social mixing, or (ii) social network mixing. The former allows each host to contact others randomly, and the key input is "mean contact rate". The latter has a rigid contact structure (social network) whereby contacts are confined to nearest neighbors (social relations). In either case the pathogen gets transmitted in a "donor-recipient" fashion. Our approach aims at more realistic patterning of human behavior at the local level (workplaces, schools et al) appropriate for Covid-like pathogens, and more general transmission pathways extending "donor-recipient" type.

Such modeling structure and setup allows us to explore a range of biological and behavioral drives of transmission and interventions. The non-pharmaceutical interventions will include, amongst others: case isolation at home or hospitals, voluntary self-quarantine, social distancing and reduction of contacts, closure or reorganization of local activities (school/working schedules in colleges/workplaces et al), personal protection (e.g. facemasks), reduced mobility, test screening and quarantine. Pharmaceutical interventions include novel vaccines and potential antiviral therapies.

Two specific IBM models were developed in the project and implemented on the Wolfram Mathematica platform. The hospital model was developed in collaboration with colleagues in Wuhan (China). It employed an outbreak dataset from a local hospital, used to calibrate and validate model parameters. It includes essential characteristics of the pathogen, social interaction in hospital settings, behavioral and prophylactic factors. The calibrated model was applied to identify the essential risk factors of infection and efficient non-pharmaceutical control strategies. 

The college model has a detailed account of campus structure, population makeup (student body) and activities (class schedule, dorm residence, social interactions). Real college data along with disease inputs can be imported into the system, alternatively a synthetic college community can be generated simulated from a few basic inputs. The model was efficiently implemented in Wolfram Mathematica, furthermore we set up a general access web tool (https://www.wolframcloud.com/obj/ait14/ibmcollegecovidmodel), whereby anyone without access to Mathematica can generate and simulate college outbreaks. The model was used to examine a wide range of college transmission environments, and intervention strategies, including class/dorm arrangement and social activities, test screening and isolation, vaccination and monitoring.

The proposed methodology, models and computer tools can have a broad impact for the ongoing Covid pandemics, and for other potential pathogens. The key innovation is our detailed account of social/behavioral factors of disease transmission, which gives an accurate account of multiple factors that affect such processes. Our models and computer tools can provide real-time information to assist public health officials and policy-makers in making critical decisions on COVID-19 control policies.
